  • LR
    Laura R
    7 hours 7h

    Mary should not have been admitted for elective surgery without attending a pre-op assessment clinic where the taking of an accurate history and appropriate pre -op teats would have resulted in appropriate optimisation before surgery. Also most elective joint replacement patients have regional anaesthesia with some form of sedation. We do not know why Mary had a GA but attendance at pre-op clinic would have allowed time to discuss the most appropriate form of anaesthesia for Mary with her pre-existing comorbidities.
    While Mary's surgery would have been delayed she would hopefully have had a better outcome.

  • LJ
    Laura Jones
    18 hours 18h

    Elderly patients and their relatives require extra support at all stages in a surgical journey..
    particularly in the initial stages when surgery is offered as a treatment option.
    Honest discussion in terms of risk, post op complications, and functional capacity post op / long term outcome. Need to be had to ensure patients and their relatives appreciate the impact a major surgical procedure is.

    Post procedure, patients require, greater care in prevent complications and assessing and managing delirium.

    Critical care stays, longer length of stay and complex discharges should be expected and planned for.

    In my experience, I often find the patient themselves appreciate, how difficult the operation will be, but it’s there relatives that push for surgery and hope that the surgical procedure will perform miracles, and their loved ones will be complexly heathy and active once it’s over. Which is often not the case.
